title: Rodrigues
common: The surname Rodrigues does not have a unique origin, because it is a patronymic meaning "Rodrigo's son". This complexity conducts Américo de Moura to list 18 different Rodrigues' families (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 446-455).

families.name: Rodrigues - São Vicente
history: All data we have about this family is present in Brazil (Almeida, João M., 1886, pp. 351-357), and these documents do not bring any information about his origin.

people.name: António Rodrigues
history:
João M. de Almeida resumes the documentation we have and, as consequence what we know about António Rodrigues (Almeida, João M., 1886, pp. 351-357), this project simplifies the reader given the sources cited in the work:
  • He owns land near a Port named Naus (Leite, Serafim, 1956, pp. 461).
  • In his work about São Vicente, Marcos A. Lança informs us about an António Rodrigues' shipyard (Lança, Marco Antônio, 2005, 106-107).
  • The work about Pero Lopes de Sousa's diary also has a citation about António Rodrigues residence being near a Port (Sousa, Pero L., 1927, pp. 203, 208, 392).
  • The Friar Gaspar Madre de Deus informs us that Martim Afonso de Sousa gave the lands near to Tumiaru to António Rodrigues, he also give us information about a "porto de Tumiaru" and gave even more details about the São Vicente region (Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, 2010, pp. 37-38).

When we talk about his family, we do not have documents to prove the relationships, but Priest Jorge Moreira wrote some memories saying "... que com João Ramalho veio Antonio Rodrigues, o qual, diz o author, casara com uma filha de Piquerobi Cacique da aldêa de Hururay." (Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, 1840, pp. 441). Américo de Moura worked with this family, informing that Luiz G. Silva Leme discovered, and published, a manuscript from Captain Diogo Gonçalves Moreira (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 446), these data can be found in the First Volume of Luiz G. Silva Leme's work, where he calls attention that they are contradictory with Pedro Taques' suggestion (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 45-47). In the next generation, I describe how genetic helps us to confirm that at least one of his [possible] daughters are in fact indigenous.

marriages.name: Desconhecida / Antonia Rodrigues
history: According to Jorge Moreira's memories (Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, 1840, pp. 441).

children.name: Gonçalo Rodrigues
history: According to Diogo Gonçalves Moreira's notes, that could be extracted from Padre Jorge Moreira's memories (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 446), these notes were published by Luis G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 45-47).

children.name: Isabel Velho
history: According to Diogo Gonçalves Moreira's notes, that could be extracted from Padre Jorge Moreira's memories (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 446), these notes were published by Luis G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 45-47).

people.name: Gonçalo Rodrigues
history: Américo de Moura describes him affirming that "Considero Garcia Rodrigues vicentino e casado na terra, não sei se uma ou mais vezes, nem com quem..." (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 447), and genetic sequencing of her [possible] daughters show that they cannot have the same mother. The relationship with his hypothetical father is not documented, and we have as the unique reference some genealogical notes letters (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 45-47).

Américo de Moura described what we know about his life, so we only list the sources that confirm them:
  • There are no documents from Santo André da Borda do Campo, but it is still possible to check data from those days through Tito Livio Ferreira's work (Ferreira, Tito Livio, 1944, pp. 72, 124,151,167, 177, 178);
  • His actions in São Paulo Town Hall are listed in "Actas" (Atas Da Câmara da Cidade de São Paulo, 1562-1596, pp. 2, 11, 12, 21, 22, 23, 24, 29, 31, 33, 34, 41, 83, 85, 105, 169);
  • It is also possible to find information in "Registro Geral da Câmara de São Paulo" (Registro Geral da Câmara de São Paulo, Volume VII, pp. 22).
  • A document from Santo André was published in Informativo Arquivo Municipal (100 anos do Arquivo Histórico Municipal: um olhar sobre o precioso acervo, pp. 4);

marriages.name: Isabel Velho
history: According to Pedro T de A. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141) and Luiz G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 45-47), probably because the unique Garcia Rodrigues' daughter that we have documentation was named as Isabel Velho.

marriages.name: Desconhecida
history: According to Américo Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 447).
The genetic sequence of mitochondrial DNA of [possible] descendants proves she has a mitochondrial haplogroup B2 (Sillos, Luiz, 2023, t. 02:12:26).

children.name: Isabel Velho
history: According to Américo Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 448) using documents present in São Paulo Town Hall (Atas Da Câmara da Cidade de São Paulo, 1623-1628, 1915, pp. 255).

children.name: Francisco Rodrigues
history: According to Américo Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 448) using documents present in São Paulo Town Hall (Atas Da Câmara da Cidade de São Paulo, 1623-1628, 1915, pp. 255).

children.name: Antonio Rodrigues
history: He cites his brothers Francisco Rodrigues, Garcia Rodrigues, Jorge Rodrigues and his brother-in-law Diogo Moreira in his inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 11, pp. 51).
According to Américo de Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 448 - 449) and Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141).

children.name: Garcia Rodrigues
history: According to Antonio Rodrigues' inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 11, pp. 51)
According to Américo de Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 449-450) and Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141).

children.name: Jorge Rodrigues
history: According to Antonio Rodrigues' inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 11, pp. 53).
According to Américo de Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 448) and Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141).

children.name: Mecia Rodrigues
history: Américo de Moura (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 448) and Luiz G. Silva Leme's hypothesis (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VII, pp. 451-452), but Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme did not follow them (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141).
She has a mitochondrial haplogroup different from Isabel Velho (Sillos, Luiz, 2023, t. 02:12:26), this means they cannot be sisters with the same parents.

children.name: Isabel Rodrigues
history: Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme does not cite this hypothesis (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141) and Américo de Moura rejects it (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 447), but Luiz G. Silva Leme suggests it (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VII, pp. 470).
The genetic sequence of her descendants confirms she has the same Mécia Rodrigues' mitochondrial haplogroup (Sillos, Luiz, 2023, t. 02:12:26).

Both Jorge Moreira and Antonio Bicudo, her husband, worked together without any impediment in Town Hall (Atas Da Câmara da Cidade de São Paulo, 1562-1596, pp. 227-252), so it is necessary to consider that either she is not Garcia Rodrigues' daughter (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 447), or some laws were too flexible to allow brothers-in-law to work together when only mothers were different (Sillos, Luiz, 2023, t. 02:15:37).

people.name: Isabel Velho
history: It was not possible to find a unique document that proves her existence (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 447), but Pedro Taques says that he could see, and this document informs that she and her husband came from Porto - PT (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141).

There is also the hypothesis that both, she and her supposed brother, are indigenous, this hypothesis is incompatible with the Pedro de A. T. Paes Leme hypothesis that they are Europeans. Before the genetic sequence to be discovered, both hypothesis had the same baseline. With the popularization of these tests, the Amarilis Paiva Almeida's son, that would be a [possible] direct descendant of Garcia Rodrigues' [possible] wife, got a complete genetic sequence of his genetic mitochondrial, that was published on YFull (YFULL, YF089441), in this genetic sequence, the mitochondrial genome is given from mother to her descendants. According to Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme's hypothesis, that informs the supposed Isabel Velho came from Porto, the expectation would be to have a mitochondrial genome from Europe. The molecular data of a [possible] Garcia Rodrigues' descendant shows that her origin is Amerindian, and this is not possible in Europe in the 16th century. The genetic sequence of Amarilis Paiva Almeida's son is exactly the same shown by Luiz Sillos for Isabel Rodrigues' descendants (Sillos, Luiz, 2023, t. 02:12:26). These results do not allow us to say nothing about Garcia Rodrigues, but they show that the supposed Isabel Velho is an Indigenous.

The mitochondrial haplogroup B2 (YFULL, YF089441 ; Sillos, Luiz, 2023, t. 02:12:26) does not allow considering her an Antonia Rodrigues' daughter, because she had mitochondrial haplogroup A2 (Sillos, Luiz, 2023, t. 00:40:52), but this result does not remove the possibility of Antonio Rodrigues to be her father.
Her supposed generation is shown in his supposed brother and husband.

marriages.name: Gonçalo Rodrigues
history: According to Pedro T de A. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Tomo III, pp. 141) and Luiz G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 45-47), probably because the unique Garcia Rodrigues' daughter that we have indirect documentation was named as Isabel Velho.
